Jonathan DiCecco

The following video showcases a Python program I made that solves sudoku puzzles efficiently with backtracking. It solves a board by pushing a number in each block from top to bottom until it finds a working number, and moves on to the next one. If there is a block where no number works, it backtracks to a previous one and tries a new combination.

This process is repeated until the board is competed.

Rules for sudoku:
- Every entry in a 3x3 square must have a unique number from 1-9
- Every column must have a unique number from 1-9
- Every row must have a unique number from 1-9

*Unfilled entries are represented by 0.
